TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi sealed beforefieldinit OracleTimeSpan extends System.ValueType implements class System.Data.SqlTypes.INullable, class System.IComparable

Docs.summary: Represents a time interval and corresponds to the Oracle 9i data type.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The Oracle `INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND` data type (Oracle 9i or later) contains an interval of time in days, hours, minutes, and seconds, and has a fixed size of 11 bytes.
To obtain an OracleTimeSpan object, call the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataReader.GetOracleTimeSpan%2A> method.

MemberSignature.Value: public int CompareTo (object obj);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance int32 CompareTo(object obj) cil managed

Docs.summary: Compares this structure to the supplied object and returns an indication of their relative values.
Docs.returns:
A signed number indicating the relative values of the instance of the structure and the object.
Return Value
Condition
Less than zero
This instance is less than the object.
Zero
This instance is the same as the object.
Greater than zero
This instance is greater than the object, or the object is a null reference ( in Visual Basic).

MemberSignature.Value: public static readonly System.Data.OracleClient.OracleTimeSpan MaxValue;
.field public static initonly valuetype System.Data.OracleClient.OracleTimeSpan MaxValue

Docs.summary: Represents the maximum valid date value for an structure.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The value is 10675199.02:48:05.4775807. To obtain a value greater than MaxValue, use the Oracle SELECT TO_CHAR statement. For more information about the ranges supported by the Oracle 9i `INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND` data type, see your Oracle documentation.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The value is -10675199.02:48:05.4775808. To obtain a value less than MinValue, use the Oracle SELECT TO_CHAR statement. For more information about the ranges supported by the Oracle 9i `INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND` data type, see your Oracle documentation.
